Philip Bertemes

PhD Student
Institute of Zoology
University of Innsbruck, Austria

About me

My name is Philip Bertemes and I am currently working as a PhD student at the Institute of Zoology (Univery of Innsbruck, Austria, Europe). I started my PhD thesis with the title "Identification and functional analysis of bioadhesives in Platyhelminthes" in August 2018. In the working group of Dr. Peter Ladurner, we are looking for novel bioadhesives in flatworms.

Synopsis

We are researching the bioadhesives produced by flatworms, or "Platyhelminthes". Those are small, simple bilatarians that live either non-parasitic or parasitic and occur in marine, brackish, and fresh water environments. Within the scope of my PhD, I am currently researching the adhesive genes of a polyclad flatworm, namely Theama mediterranea. I have worked with this species in the past, since I made my Master thesis on its regeneration capacities (Bertemes et al. 2020). To find the adhesive genes (and proteins), we use a broad molecular toolbox including transcriptomics, proteomics, and genomics to find and charactarise those non-toxic and reversible biomimetic glues. I want to assemble a draft genome of this animal using a new sequencing technology known as Nanopore sequencing.

The past

For the model organism in flatworms, Macrostomum lignano, we now have an excellent genome as well as a transcriptome. With the first draft de novo transcriptome of M. lignano, Wunderer et al. (2019) found multiple transcripts that are relevant for the production of adhesion proteins. With in situ hybridisation, we were able to show that those transcripts are only expressed in the tail. With RNA interference (RNAi), we were able to demonstrate that multiple transcripts must be part of one bigger transcript that was not assembled correctly. When the genome of M. lignano became accessible and genome-guided transcriptome assembly was possible, it assembled correctly in a single large fragment. A lot of effort was put into finding all the short transcripts and checking for their dependencies - Work that could have been avoided if a genome-draft would have been available.

The present

In my PhD thesis, I want to make use of the most recent advantages in sequencing technology. We can currently easily access "third generation sequencing", which produce ultra long reads for a relatively low cost. Namely, I am currently operating an Oxford Nanopore MinION device, with which I was already able to produce genomic reads with a length of over 250.000 base pairs. As a proof-of-principle, we published (Pjeta et al. 2019) adhesion canditates from the proseriate flatworm Minona ileanae, and only recently found out with a new Nanopore run (at our institute) that the repetitive region in one of the M. ileanae adhesion related genes could be potentially over 45.000 bases long.

The future

It is my current goal to extract high molecular weight genomic DNA to produce ultra-long reads with a novel sequencing method. The short Illumina reads (150 base pairs long) that we have at the moment cannot be assembled correctly in the repeat regions of the large adhesive genes. Also, because the adhesive genes are usually very long, the Transcriptome-Assembler will produce many unrelated short transcripts instead of one long contiguous transcript. The long reads that we will sequence on an Oxford Nanopore MinION device can be assembled into a draft genome that will significantly improve and facilitate all downstream analysis which I will tackle within the scope of my PhD.

Acquired skills during the PhD

  • DNA/RNA extraction of different flatworms
  • cDNA library synthesis from extracted RNA
  • Cloning of candidate genes into competent bacteria
  • Digoxigenin-labelled RNA probe synthesis
  • Whole mount in situ hybridisation with different taxa
  • Protein pulldown with Lectin on Macrostomum lignano
  • Mass spectrometry preparation
  • DNA library preparation for Oxford Nanopore sequencing
  • Superresolution microscopy (gSTED cLSM, Leica TCS SP8 STED)
  • Electron microscopy (Transmission and Scanning EM)
  • Trinity transcriptome assembly on a Linux Workstation (maintained by myself)
  • CANU draft genome assembly on a Linux High Performance Computer-Cluster (maintained by the University)
  • many many many linux tools usefull during genome and transcriptome assembly, annotation, mapping, quantifying, ...

My funding

36-months PhD scholarship (01.12.2019 - 30.11.2022) from the "Fonds National de la Recherche Luxembourg (FNR)".
12-months PhD scholarship (01.11.2018 - 31.10.2019) from the "Vizerektorat für Forschung, Doktoratsstipendien aus der Nachwuchsförderung der LFU".
